Welcome to Minesweeper’s documentation!¶

class main.Main[source]¶

Source file for project. Creates instance of Menu class, begins game by the rules and menu

Attributes:
playing: Instance of the Menu class
class executive.Executive(root, setup_callback)[source]¶

Executive class to act as game manager

Attributes:

game_over: Boolean to record current game status

cheat_mode: Boolean to record whether or not user is in cheat mode

myBoard: Instance of the Board class

root: tk root widget instance

setup_callback: function to call to re-show setup window

stopwatch: instance of stopwatch

flag_img: tk photoimage instance for the flag

cheat_button: button to click in order to cheat

cheat()[source]¶

Run when user enters cheat mode

check_win()[source]¶

Checks if all mines are flagged to determine is user has won the game

Calls on_game_win function if the user has won

exit_cheat()[source]¶

function to call to hide the cheat board and reset cheat flag

flag_event(x, y)[source]¶

Performs necessary actions when a cell is flagged/unflagged (right clicked)

Args:

x: x-position of the cell flagged

y: y-position of the cell flagged

hide_windows()[source]¶

hides windows and stops processes associated with them

on_game_lose()[source]¶

Run when user clicks on a mine

on_game_win()[source]¶

Run when user has flagged all mines

reveal_event(x, y)[source]¶

Performs necessary actions when a cell is clicked on

Args:

x: x-position of the cell clicked

y: y-position of the cell clicked

setup(width, height, mines)[source]¶

Generates board to spec of user input

Then shows board window and game status window

Args:

width: width of the board to setup

height: height of the board to setup

mines: number of mines in the board to setup

class menu.Menu(root)[source]¶

Menu class to act as game menu

Attributes:

setup: Instance of the Setup class for getting user input to setup the board

root: instance of Tk root window

rules_window: tkinter window for the rules to display in

rules_displayed: flag if the rules are currently displayed or not

game_rules()[source]¶

Reads game instructions from game_instructions.txt and prints data

start_game()[source]¶

Hides main menu window and displays the board setup window

class square.Square(master, x, y, click_callback, rclick_callback, **options)[source]¶

Square class for managing properties of a square in Minesweeper

Attributes:

is_mine: Boolean to record whether or not a square is a mine

is_flagged: Boolean to record whether or not a square is flagged

is_revealed: Boolean to record whether or not a square is revealed

num_adj_mines: Integer to record number of mines adjacent to square

was_moved: Boolean to record whether or not a square has been moved

flag_img: Tk photoimage object of the flag

mine_img: Tk photoimage object of the mine

color_mapping: mapping of colors for each number of mines

flag()[source]¶

flags the cell - sets property and displays image in cell

freeze()[source]¶

removes bindings for mouse buttons - used for cheat mode and when game ends, to prevent user from editing cell

reveal()[source]¶

reveals the cell - sets property, number of mines in cell, mine image (if this cell is a mine), and relief to sunken

unflag()[source]¶

unflags the cell - sets property and hides image from cell

class board.Board(root, hide_callback)[source]¶

Board class that handles game board creation and functionality

Attributes:

width: Integer for width of the board

height: Integer for height of the board

mines_num: Integer for recording number of mines

num_flags: Integer for recording number of flags

grid: 2D array to store Square instances that make up board

first_selection: Boolean for recording whether or not an interaction is
the user’s first interaction

board_window: tk toplevel window instance for board

checkAdditionalReveals()[source]¶

Ensures Squares that were already revealed but were changed to 0 after the mines moved are revealed properly

count_nearby_mines(x, y, width, height)[source]¶

Counts the number of adjacent mines for a given Square

Args:

x: Integer coordinate of Square on the x-axis

y: Integer coordinate of Square on the y-axis

width: Integer for width of board

height: Integer for height of board

generate_mines(mines, width, height)[source]¶

Randomly places mines on board

Args:

mines: Integer number of mines to be used

width: Integer for width of board

height: Integer for height of board

gridSquares()[source]¶

place all the squares into the board window

hide_board_window()[source]¶

performs actions to properly hide the board window

is_valid_cell(x, y)[source]¶

Checks that coordinates are within bounds of the board

Args:

x: Integer coordinate on the x-axis

y: Integer coordinate on the y-axis

make_grid(width, height, reveal_callback, flag_callback)[source]¶

Populates grid to user specification

Args:

width: Integer for width of board

height: Integer for height of board

reveal_callback: function to call when a square is revealed

flag_callback: function to call when a square is flagged

Returns:
grid: Populated 2D array to act as game board
mine_check(width, height)[source]¶

Assigns number of adjacent mines for each Square to the Square member variable

Args:

width: Integer width of the board

height: Integer height of the board

moveMines()[source]¶

Moves mines to a location that is not revealed nor is a mine

print_board(width, height, main_grid)[source]¶

Prints a formatted game board, followed by making a call to print a formatted time from stopwatch

Args:

width: Integer for width of board

height: Integer for height of board

main_grid: 2D array to be printed

resetGridMineCount()[source]¶

Resets number of adjacent mines to 0 before evaluating the board

reveal(x, y)[source]¶

Recursively calls reveal_adajenct to reveal Squares

Args:

x: Integer coordinate on the x-axis

y: Integer coordinate on the y-axis

reveal_adjacent(x, y)[source]¶

Reveals cells that aren’t mines

Args:

x: Integer coordinate on the x-axis

y: Integer coordinate on the y-axis

ungridSquares()[source]¶

remove all the squares from the board window

validTransformation(tolerance, x, y)[source]¶

Determines if moved mines are moved properly

Args:

tolerance: Integer weight for propability of successful move

x: Integer coordinate on the x-axis

y: Integer coordinate on the y-axis

Returns:

True if valid transformation
class stopwatch.Stopwatch(root)[source]¶

Simple stopwatch class with functionality for starting, stopping, and resetting

Attributes:

start_time: Integer to record time (0 seconds) that stopwatch was
started

formatted_time: stores a formatted time string of the current time

root: tkinter root widget - needed for timer periodic callbacks

last_after: stores last last timer callback, so that it can be cancelled when the timer is stopped

reset()[source]¶

resets the formatted time to string of 0s

start()[source]¶

Starts stopwatch by setting the start_time to time.time(), rounded to the nearest whole number

Then makes a periodic callback to update the formatted time in 200 ms

stop()[source]¶

Stops stopwatch by removing the latest callback

class setup.Setup(root, menu_callback)[source]¶

Creates and provides functions for window to take in board specifications from user.

Attributes:

exec: instance of executive class, for actually playing the game with

root: instance of tk root window

menu_callback: function to call when the setup window is closed, to re-show the main menu window

setup_window: instance of tk window for input of board parameters

width_input: tk entry for user to put width value in

height_input: tk entry for user to put height value in

mines_input: tk entry for suer to put mines count in

validate()[source]¶

checks if the user’s inputs are valid, and starts the game if they are

window_functions.center_window(window)[source]¶

centers the given window/widget on the screen

Args:

window: the tk window (root/toplevel) instance to center
window_functions.position_window(window, x, y)[source]¶

sends the given window to the given x, y position

Args:

window: the tk window (root/toplevel) instance to move

x: pixel x-position to move to

y: pixel y-position to move to
